qas.question: When did Canada finally cease to use the traditional ceremony for granting assent as regular practice?
Why was King George VI's personal assent in 1939 noteworthy?

answers.text: 85 years after his great-grandmother, Queen Victoria, had last granted royal assent personally

qas.question: With what bill in Canada did granting assent by writing become effective?
In Chile, the ceremony for granting assent was used until what century?
What king assented to nineteen bills of the Canadian parliament during the 1939 royal tour?
Who was King George VI's grandmother?

plausible_answers.text: a failure to employ the traditional ceremony where required

qas.question: A grant of royal assent is rendered invalid by what?

context: In Canada, the traditional ceremony for granting assent in parliament was regularly used until <a0_0>the <b3_0>21st<b3_0/> century<a0_0/>, long after it had been discontinued in the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth realms. One result, conceived as part of a string of royal duties intended to demonstrate Canada's status as an independent kingdom, was that <b4_0>King George VI<b4_0/> personally assented to nine bills of the Canadian parliament during the 1939 royal tour of Canada—<a1_0>85 years after his great-grandmother, <b5_0>Queen Victoria<b5_0/>, had last granted royal assent personally<a1_0/> in the United Kingdom. Under the <a2_0>Royal Assent Act 2002<a2_0/>, however, the alternative practice of granting assent in writing, with each house being notified separately ( the Speaker of the Senate or a representative reads to the senators the letters from the governor general regarding the written declaration of Royal Assent), was brought into force. As the act also provides, royal assent is to be signified—by the governor general, or, more often, by a deputy, usually a Justice of the Supreme Court, at least twice each calendar year: for the first appropriation measure and for at least one other act, usually the first non-appropriation measure passed. However, the act provides that a grant of royal assent is not rendered invalid by <b6_0>a failure to employ the traditional ceremony where required<b6_0/>.
